body:
> Can you reproduce the bug on the Gitea demo site?

As far as I know, LFS is turned off there, and in any case it will not be a very good idea to upload such a large file there.

Could you provide a diagnosis report from admin panel -> monitor -> trace? "Download diagnosis report", when the memory leak occurs.

----

If it isn't a real memory leak (the memory will be recycled eventually after the requests) but just "writes the entire file to RAM" and causes out-of-memory, then it could be another problem. Maybe it could be reproduced by the SSH LFS test code.

No problem!
Should i wipe some private data there?

> If it isn't a real memory leak (the memory will be recycled eventually after the requests

Sorry, it seems I used the wrong terminology.
The memory is really released after the file upload is completed, probably this cannot be considered a memory leak.

The generated "heap" file doesn't contain sensitive data. It looks like this:

<details>


![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4b25f2c4-7a86-4af1-9c57-dc75c355bdcb)


</details>


----

And thank you for the update, I think we do not need the diagnosis report now ...... just need to reproduce it by the SSH LFS tests.

Hi @Danstiv,

yes, the LFS SSH proxy reads the entire file into memory before uploads/downloads. More specifically, at these points:

`GiteaBackend.Download()`:
https://github.com/go-gitea/gitea/blob/4af6417c71ab21f55fc65fa018c36a2777d6960f/modules/lfstransfer/backend/backend.go#L199

`GiteaBackend.Upload()`:
https://github.com/go-gitea/gitea/blob/4af6417c71ab21f55fc65fa018c36a2777d6960f/modules/lfstransfer/backend/backend.go#L237

(There are other calls to `io.ReadAll()`, but they're for comparatively tiny JSON files, and necessary because `json.Unmarshal()` only accepts bytes.)

Those calls to `io.ReadAll()` can be removed and just the reader can be passed around to potentially reduce memory usage, but you will need to verify that _somewhere_ down the stack those readers are closed.
We need to read/write the stream on the fly, but not fill into memory.

body:
Docker image 1.23-nightly is ready (it is a stable release and will be 1.23.2 soon), could you try whether there is still any problem?

* https://hub.docker.com/r/gitea/gitea/tags?name=1.23-nightly

Small files are uploaded correctly.
When uploading 1GB file, I do not see increasing of RAM useage or disk usage, at the end of git shows an error.
```
D:\temp\test>git push
got status 500 when uploading OID 6070d6b0f6f841d76171143017f17a44cad4ad4ade5719b239ef198851f5b37d: internal error
error: failed to push some refs to 'gt:Danstiv/test'
```

> Small files are uploaded correctly. When uploading 1GB file, I do not see increasing of RAM useage or disk usage

Good to hear that, then the memory problem seems to have been resolved.


> at the end of git shows an error.

Do you have Gitea's logs? If 500 error occurs, there must be some server side error logs.

Just use the test code to push a 2G file via SSH LFS, it seems to be fine.


![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e4067674-ab2e-4d49-ba5a-72518fc4ac37)

My log configuration:
```
[log]
LEVEL = trace
MODE = file
```
Strange, don't see LFS upload related request there. The "upload" request is something like `PUT .../objects/{oid}/{size} ... (lfs.UploadHandler)`

At the moment I have no idea about how to debug the problem without more clues. Maybe you could:

* try another LFS file to see whether it is related to a specific file (already uploaded/corrupted on server side? still a bug)
* try to use some debug flags to see what happens in git-lfs
* make a reproducible repo or provide detailed steps to construct a demo repo, then maintainers could try to reproduce on their side.

(and open a new issue)
